name: Hafnon
caption: Very small brown single crystals of hafnon from Bernic Lake, Lac-du-Bonnet District, Manitoba, Canada
habit: Euhedral to irregular crystals
impurities: Often zoned with zircon. Forms part of zircon-hafnon series

name: Cerianite-(Ce)
caption: Yellow powder of the very rare mineral cerianite-(Ce) from Morro do Ferro, Caldas, Minas Gerais, [[Brazil]].
habit: octahedra; earthy, massive
color: Dark greenish amber-yellow, yellow, buff

name: Thorite
caption: Thorite crystal from the Kemp uranium mine in Ontario (size: 2.2 x 2.2 x 1.6 cm)
habit: In square prisms, or pseudo-octahedral crystals; also massive
streak: Light orange to light brown sometimes even an alien magenta
diaphaneity: Nearly opaque, transparent in thin fragments
color: Yellow-orange, brownish yellow, brownish black, black, green

name: Zircon
caption: A lustrous crystal of zircon perched on a tan matrix of calcite from the [[Gilgit District]] of Pakistan
habit: tabular to prismatic crystals, irregular grains, massive
color: Reddish brown, yellow, green, blue, gray, colorless; in thin section, colorless to pale brown
twinning: On {101}. Crystals shocked by meteorite impact show polysynthetic twins on {112}
fusibility: close to 2,550 °C depend on Hf,Th,U,H,etc... concentrations.

name: Coffinite
caption: [[Uraninite|Pitchblende]] and coffinite in a sample from a Czech mine
habit: Rarely as crystals, commonly as colloform to botryoidal incrustations, fibrous, pulverulent masses
color: Black (from organic inclusions; pale to dark brown in [[thin section]]
pleochroism: Moderate; pale yellow-brown parallel to and medium brown perpendicular to long axis

name: William Niven
caption: William Niven, mineralogist, circa 1895

name: Fayalite
image: Fayalite crystal group - Ochtendung, Eifel, Germany.jpg
caption: Fayalite crystals on substrate. Sample collected from Ochtendung, Eifel, Germany
habit: Commonly granular, compact, or massive
color: Greenish yellow, yellow-brown, brown; pale yellow to amber in thin section

name: Forsterite
image: Forsterite on Sanidine - Ochtendung, Eifel, Germany.jpg
caption:
Forsterite (big tabular and colorless) on [[sanidine]] (little colorless crystals)
with [[hematite]] (reddish)
habit: Dipyramidal prisms often tabular, commonly granular or compact massive
color: Colorless, green, yellow, yellow green, white

name: Bunsenite
image: Bunsenite - Kochhütte, Helbra, Mansfeld-Südharz, Saxony-Anhalt, Germany.jpg
caption: Bunsenite with unknown colorless crystals from the collection of the „Verein zur Förderung der Lithothek e.V.“ Munich (collection number A022658). Field of view 1 mm. Locality: Kochhütte, Helbra, Mansfeld-Südharz, Saxony-Anhalt, [[Germany]]
habit: Octahedral crystal coatings, also cube or dodecahedron forms
color: Dark pistachio-green

name: Olivine
habit: Massive to granular
color: Yellow to yellow-green

name: Tephroite
image: Tephroite Manganese silicate Kaao Mine Tochigi-ken Honshu Japan 1816.jpg
caption: Tephroite from Japan
habit: Crystals typically short, prismatic, to 4 cm, or anhedral, equidimensional. Commonly in disseminated grains, compact, or massive.
color: Olive-green, bluish green, gray, °esh-red, reddish brown; pale green in thin section, may be colorless
pleochroism: Weak; X = brownish red; Y = reddish; Z = greenish blue.

name: Phenakite
caption: Phenakite crystals
habit: Tabular, prismatic to acicular crystals often as columnar aggregates, as spherulites and granular
color: Colorless, yellow, pink, brown

name: Willemite
caption: Willemite from [[Namibia]]
habit: Fibrous, [[botryoidal]] to massive
color: Colorless to white, gray, black, flesh-red, burgundy-red, pink, brown, dark brown, mahogany-brown, honey-yellow, yellow, apple-green, blue, pastel green, light blue, azure-blue

name: Eucryptite
caption: Eucryptite grains in albite from the type locality (size:9.3 x 7.0 x 2.8 cm)
habit: Rare as euhedral crystals, coarse crystalline aggregates and massive
color: Brown, colorless, white
other: Fluoresces pink to red or orange under SW UV

name: Sillimanite
habit: Prismatic crystals, fibrous, acicular
color: Colourless or white to grey, also brown, yellow, yellow-green, grey-green, blue-green, blue; colourless in thin section
pleochroism: Colourless to pale brown to yellow

name: Mullite
image: Osumilite, thick tabulars with Mullite - Ochtendung, Eifel, Germany.jpg
caption:
White, filamentous mullite in front of thicker [[osumilite]] platelets
(Photo width 1.5 mm)
Found in Wannenköpfe, [[Ochtendung]], [[Eifel]], Germany
habit: Prismatic to acicular crystals
color: Colorless to pale pink or grey

name: Andalusite
caption: Andalusite
habit: As euhedral crystals or columnar aggregates having nearly square cross sections; fibrous compact to massive
opticalprop: double refractive, biaxial negative; ''chiastolite'' has anomalous aggregate reaction.
diaphaneity: Transparent to nearly opaque with inclusions
color: Pink, violet, yellow, green, white, gray; in thin section, colorless to pink or green

name: Kyanite
habit: Columnar; fibrous; bladed
mohs:
4.5-5 parallel to one axis
6.5-7 perpendicular to that axis
color: Blue, white, rarely green, light gray to gray, rarely yellow, pink, orange, and black, can be zoned
pleochroism: Trichroic, colorless to pale blue to blue

name: Titanite (Sphene)
image: Titanite crystals on Amphibole - Ochtendung, Eifel, Germany.jpg
caption: Titanite crystals on amphibole (image width 2 mm)
habit: Flattened wedge-shaped crystals, also massive
colour: Reddish brown, brown, gray, black, yellow, green, or red, colourless
twinning: Contact and penetration on {100}, lamellar on {221}
pleochroism: Strong: X = nearly colorless; Y = yellow to green; Z = red to yellow-orange

name: Malayaite
caption: Malayaite found in the United Kingdom
habit: Massive or wedge shaped
color: Colorless, greenish gray, white, light yellow, orange
other: Fluorescent, Short UV = bright yellowish green

name: Cerite
caption: Cerite - Bastnas - Deposit Topotype
habit: Massive granular
color: Clove-brown with a reddish tinge; pale lavender-brown to colorless in thin fragments

name: Britholite-(Ce)
caption: A photo of the mineral
colour: Brown, greenish brown, yellow, resin brown, black
var1text: 5.5 on the [[Mohs scale of hardness|Mohs scale]]

name: '''Fluorellestadite'''
caption: Fluorellestadite on blue calcite from the Crestmore Quarries, California, US
habit: Acicular or hexagonal prismatic crystals, and fine-grained aggregates
streak: White with a weak bluish tint
color: Light red, yellow, bluish green or colorless
solubility: Easily soluble in dilute hydrochloric and nitric acids

constituency_westminster: [[Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale (UK Parliament constituency)|Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale]]

name: Cuprosklodowskite
caption: Cuprosklodowskite,  [[Musonoi mine]], [[Kolwezi]], [[Lualaba District]], Democratic Republic of the Congo {3.6 x 2.7 x 2.2 cm}
habit: In radiating groups of [[Acicular (crystal habit)|acicular]] flattened or bladed needles or fibrous crusts
color: Yellowish to grass-green
pleochroism: X = nearly colorless; Y = Z = yellowish green

name: Uranophane
habit: Crystals occur as stellate needle aggregates;  as fibrous crusts, and massive
luster: Vitreous to pearly; waxy or dull when massive
fluorescence: Weak yellow-green under both short and long UV
color: Light yellow, lemon-yellow, honey-yellow, straw-yellow, green-yellow
pleochroism: Weak; X = colorless; Y = pale canary-yellow; Z = canary-yellow

name: Sklodowskite
caption: Sklodowskite on [[gypsum]]

name: Cuprosklodowskite
caption: Cuprosklodowskite,  [[Musonoi mine]], [[Kolwezi]], [[Lualaba District]], Democratic Republic of the Congo {3.6 x 2.7 x 2.2 cm}
habit: In radiating groups of [[Acicular (crystal habit)|acicular]] flattened or bladed needles or fibrous crusts
color: Yellowish to grass-green
pleochroism: X = nearly colorless; Y = Z = yellowish green

name: Boltwoodite
caption: Acicular crystals of umber-yellow boltwoodite from Namibia (size: 1.8 x 1.7 x 1.4 cm)
habit: Elongated crystals, acicular to fibrous
luster: Silky to vitreous, dull or earthy in aggregates
fluorescence: Fluoresces dull green in both SW and LW UV
color: Pale yellow, orange yellow

name: Datolite
caption: Datolite on sphalerite from San Luis Potosí, Mexico (size: 6.2 x 5.3 x 2.8 cm)
habit: Crystal prismatic, short to tabular; Botryoidal or globular with columnar structure; granular to compact; cryptocrystalline
luster: Vitreous, rarely subresinous on fracture surface
color: Colorless or white; may be grayish, yellow, green, pale green, red, pink, etc.

name: Bakerite
caption: Bakerite sample
color: Colorless, white

name: Gadolinite
caption: Gadolinite (black portion at top)

name: Pyrope
habit: [[Euhedral|Euhedra]] typically display [[Rhombic dodecahedron|rhombic dodecahedral]] form, but [[Trapezohedron|trapezohedra]] are not uncommon, and hexoctahedra are seen in some rare samples. Massive and granular forms also occur.
opticalprop: Single refractive, often anomalous double refractive
refractive: 1.74 normal, but ranges from 1.714 to over 1.742
color: Blood red to black red, red, orange red, pink,  some varieties are very dark, almost black, while others can take tones of purple to purple red, Some [[chromium]]-rich pyropes are [[thermochromic]], becoming green when heated.
solubility: Insoluble in water, weakly soluble in [[Hydrofluoric acid|HF]]
absorption: broad band at 564nm with cutoff at 440 to 445nm. Fine gem quality pyropes may show [[chromium]] lines in the red end of the spectrum

name: Almandine
opticalprop: Single refractive, and often anomalous double refractive
color: reddish orange to red, slightly purplish red to reddish purple and usually dark in tone
absorption: usually at 504, 520, and 573nm, may also have faint lines at 423, 460, 610 and 680-690nm

name: Spessartine
caption: Spessartine crystals on larger quartz crystals from China
habit: Massive to crystalline
color: Yellow through red
absorption: Bands at 410, 420, 430 nm (or merging to form cutoff below 430 nm; also bands at 460, 480, 520 nm. Possible weak bands at 504 or 573 nm

name: Garnet
habit: [[Rhombic dodecahedron]] or cubic
opticalprop: Single refractive, often anomalous double refractive
color: virtually all colors, blue is very rare

name: Majorite
habit: Microcrystalline aggregates; acicular to equant grains in narrow veinlets
color: Purple, pale yellowish brown, colorless
gravity: Measured at about 4; 3.51 (calculated for pure MgSiO<sub>3</sub>)

name: calderite
caption: Calderite crystals on matrix from [[Sunndal]] [[Norway]]
color: brownish red to brownish yellow
alt: Dark red hexoctahedral crystals on light colored rock

name: Andradite
caption: Single crystal (4.2cm) – Diakon, Nioro du Sahel Circle, Kayes Region, Mali
habit: Commonly well-crystallized dodecahedra, trapezohedra, or combinations, also granular to massive
color: Yellow, greenish yellow to emerald-green, dark green; brown, brownish red, brownish yellow; grayish black, black; may be sectored
var3text: transparent to translucent yellow, may show [[chatoyancy]]
var1text: transparent light to dark green to yellow-green
absorption: demantoid – 440nm band or complete absorption at 440nm and below, may also have lines at 618, 634, 685, 690nm

name: Grossular
caption: Grossular [[dodecahedron]], 7 mm across, from [[Coahuila]], Mexico
opticalprop: Single refractive, often anomalous double refractive
fluorescence: near colorless to light green – inert to weak orange in longwave and weak yellow-orange in shortwave; yellow – inert to weak orange in longwave and shortwave
color:
light to dark green, light to dark yellow to reddish brown, brown, orange, red, yellow, green, white, occasionally translucent to opaque pink. It is also but rarely 
found in colorless form
absorption: Hessonite sometimes shows bands at 407 and 430nm
var4text: translucent to opaque pink grossularite crystals in [[marble]] from Mexico

name: Uvarovite
habit: Euhedral crystals, granular, massive
color: Green, emerald-green, green-black
other: [[Fluorescent]] red in both short and long UV

name: Goldmanite
caption: Goldmanite from Slovakia
habit: Dodecahedral crystals and anhedral grains
color: Green, brownish–green

name: Garnet
habit: [[Rhombic dodecahedron]] or cubic
opticalprop: Single refractive, often anomalous double refractive
color: virtually all colors, blue is very rare

name: Garnet
habit: [[Rhombic dodecahedron]] or cubic
opticalprop: Single refractive, often anomalous double refractive
color: virtually all colors, blue is very rare

name: Garnet
habit: [[Rhombic dodecahedron]] or cubic
opticalprop: Single refractive, often anomalous double refractive
color: virtually all colors, blue is very rare

name: Hydrogrossular
habit: [[Crystal habit|Massive]]
color: green to bluish green, pink, white, gray
absorption: dark green hydrogrossular often shows cutoff below 460 nm. Other color stones may show line around 463 nm, indicating some [[idocrase]] content

name: Hydrogrossular
habit: [[Crystal habit|Massive]]
color: green to bluish green, pink, white, gray
absorption: dark green hydrogrossular often shows cutoff below 460 nm. Other color stones may show line around 463 nm, indicating some [[idocrase]] content

name: Garnet
habit: [[Rhombic dodecahedron]] or cubic
opticalprop: Single refractive, often anomalous double refractive
color: virtually all colors, blue is very rare

name: Topaz
caption: Topaz crystal on white matrix
habit: Prismatic crystal
color: Colorless (if no impurities), white, blue, brown, orange, gray, yellow, yellowish brown, green, pink and reddish pink, red
pleochroism: Weak in thick sections X = yellow; Y = yellow, violet, reddish; Z = violet, bluish, yellow, pink

name: '''Krieselite'''
caption: Krieselite, from Tsumeb, Namibia
habit: Isotypic with topaz
color: Beige to white

name: Alleghanyite
caption: Alleghanyite crystals up to 2 mm in size in a mixed [[franklinite]]/[[calcite]]/[[willemite]] block of 11×6.5×4 cm size. Location: Sterling Mine, Sussex County, New Jersey, US.
habit: Granular; anhedral to subhedral crystals in matrix
color: Brown, bright pink, grayish pink, white

name: '''Chondrodite'''
habit: Typically anhedral masses or grains, or as plates flattened on {010}, {001} or {100}.
color: Yellow, orange, red or brown, rarely colorless
other: Some specimens fluoresce orange yellow under shortwave and orange under longwave UV.  Not radioactive.
twinning: Simple or multiple twinning common on {001}, also reported on {105} and {305}.
pleochroism: X golden yellow to orange, Y and Z light yellow to almost colorless

name: Humite
caption: Humite specimen, Italy
color: White, yellow, dark orange, brown

name: Leucophoenicite
caption: Leucophoenicite from the Wessels Mine in [[Kuruman]], South Africa.

name: Galaxite
caption: Galaxite from the Kaso mine, Japan
habit: Octahedra and rounded grains and exolution blebs
diaphaneity: Opaque; may be translucent in thin section
color: Black, red-brown, red to yellow
twinning: Spinel law with {111} as both twin and composition plane

name: Clinohumite
habit: Granular, prismatic, twinned
color: Brownish to orange, yellow, red
pleochroism: X = golden yellow, yellow-brown, deep reddish yellow; Y = pale yellow, yellow-orange, light yellow; Z = pale yellow, yellow-orange, colorless

name: Jerrygibbsite
caption: Jerrygibbsite (pink) found in New Jersey
habit: Interlocking anhedral crystals
color: Violet-pink, with a brownish tinge

name: Sonolite
caption: Sonolite (in bottom left corner) with [[zincite]] and [[manganosite]]
color:
Red-orange, pinkish brown to dark brown
Colorless in thin section

name: '''Norbergite'''
caption: Norbergite crystals on calcite from Oakssaung Hill, Mogok, Mandalay, Burma (size: 4.2 x 3.3 x 2.3 cm)
habit: Granular, tabular crystals rare
color: Tan, yellow, yellow-orange, orange-brown, pink with purplish tint, white
other: May fluoresce canary-yellow under SW UV
pleochroism: Pleochroism: X = pale yellow; Y = very pale yellow; Z = colorless

name: Chloritoid
caption: Chloritoid crystal group on matrix from Nuristan Province, Afghanistan (size:6.3 x 3.5 x 3.0 cm)
unit cell:
1A polytype: a = 9.46 Å,
b = 5.50 Å, c = 9.15 Å;
α = 97.05°, β = 101.56°,
γ = 90.10°
2M polytype: a = 9.50 Å,
b = 5.50 Å, c = 18.22 Å;
β = 101.9°; Z = 4
habit:
Tabular pseudohexagonal crystals; rosettes, commonly coarsely foliated with foliae
typically curved or bent; also massive
cleavage: Perfect on {001}, distinct on {110}; parting on {010}
streak: White, grayish, or very slightly greenish
color: Dark gray, greenish gray, greenish black
twinning: Common on {001}, polysynthetic may be lamellar
pleochroism: X = olive-green to yellow; Y = grayish blue to blue; Z = colorless to pale greenish yellow

name: Ottrelite
caption: Ottrelite
habit: Granular
color: Pistachio green

name: Clinozoisite
image: Clinozoisite, Amphibole Group - Mount Belvidere Quarries, Vermont, USA.jpg
caption: Clinozoisite
habit: Elongated primatic crystals, striated; granular to fibrous
color: Colorless, green, gray, light green, yellow green, pink

name: Epidote
caption: Epidote crystals
habit: Prismatic with striations, fibrous, massive
color: Pistachio-green, yellow-green, greenish black, brownish-green, green, black

name: Epidote
caption: Epidote crystals
habit: Prismatic with striations, fibrous, massive
color: Pistachio-green, yellow-green, greenish black, brownish-green, green, black

name: Piemontite
caption: Piémontite from the type locality: Prabornaz Mine, Italy
habit: Slender prismatic, blocky to massive

name: Allanite
image: Allanite-(Ce) - Mary Kathleen Mine, Mount Isa, Queensland, Australia.jpg
caption: Allanite from the Mt. Isa – Cloncurry area, Queensland, Australia (scale bar 1 inch)
habit: Crystals tabular, prismatic to acicular; granular, massive; commonly metamict
color: Brown to black
pleochroism:
''X'' = pale olive-green, reddish brown;
''Y'' = dark brown, brownish yellow;
''Z'' = dark reddish brown, greenish brown

name: '''Dollaseite-(Ce)'''
habit: Massive, somewhat prismatic, equant when subhedral
cleavage: Indistinct, epidote has one good cleavage on one side
color: Brown

name: Håleniusite-(La)
caption: Håleniusite-(La) (yellow) with other minerals

name: '''Dollaseite-(Ce)'''
habit: Massive, somewhat prismatic, equant when subhedral
cleavage: Indistinct, epidote has one good cleavage on one side
color: Brown

name: Tourmaline
habit: Parallel and elongated. Acicular prisms, sometimes radiating. Massive. Scattered grains (in granite).
birefringence: -0.018 to −0.040; typically about .020 but in dark stones it may reach .040
fluorescence: pink stones—inert to very weak red to violet in long and short wave
color: Most commonly black, but can range from colorless to brown, red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet, pink, or hues in between; can be bi-colored, or even tri-colored; rarely can be neon green or electric blue
alt: A stone cut open and polished, revealing a bright rainbow of colors
absorption: Strong narrow band at 498 nm, and almost complete absorption of red down to 640 nm in blue and green stones; red and pink stones show lines at 458 and 451 nm as well as a broad band in the green spectrum
pleochroism:
{{plainlist|
*Typically moderate to strong|ref| name="GRG" |
*Red: definite; dark red, light red
*Green: strong; dark green, yellow-green
*Brown: definite; dark brown, light brown
*Blue: strong; dark blue, light blue}} *Red: definite; dark red, light red
*Green: strong; dark green, yellow-green
*Brown: definite; dark brown, light brown
*Blue: strong; dark blue, light blue

*Brown: definite; dark brown, light brown
*Blue: strong; dark blue, light blue

name: '''Fluor-liddicoatite'''
caption: Liddicoatite from the Ambesabora [[pegmatite]], Madagascar.  Photo Rob Lavinsky
habit: Stout prismatic, with a curved convex trigonal outline
color: Usually smoky brown, but also pink, red, green, blue, or rarely white.
pleochroism: Strong: O dark brown or pink, E light brown or pale pink

name: Fluor-uvite
caption: Uvite on quartz
color: Black, greenish-black, brownish-black, brown, green, colorless

name: Fluor-buergerite
color: Bronze, Dark Brown, Black, Dark Purple

caption: The crystals here are black, lustrous, and 1-2mm in size. They richly cover one side of the matrix, and the povondraite winds its way through the fissures in the rock.
habit: Prismatic, striated

name: Elbaite
image: Elbaite with albite - São José da Safira, Minas Gerais, Brazil.jpg
habit: Prismatic; striated
color: Green, red to pink, blue, orange, yellow, colorless, multicolored

absorption: Strong narrow band at 498 nm, and almost complete absorption of red down to 640 nm in blue and green stones; red and pink stones show lines at 458 and 451 nm as well as a broad band in the green spectrum
pleochroism:
{{plainlist|
*Typically moderate to strong|ref| name="GRG" |
*Red: definite; dark red, light red
*Green: strong; dark green, yellow-green
*Brown: definite; dark brown, light brown
*Blue: strong; dark blue, light blue}} *Red: definite; dark red, light red
*Green: strong; dark green, yellow-green
*Brown: definite; dark brown, light brown
*Blue: strong; dark blue, light blue

habit: Prismatic crystals, commonly lamellar, fibrous, or massive
color: White, grey, green, yellow or brown - colorless in thin section.

habit: Short prismatic crystals common, may be granular, columnar, massive

habit: massive, prismatic crystals

name: Jadeite
caption: Jadeite from [[Burma]]
habit: Commonly massive, or fibrous, granular; prismatic crystals rare
fluorescence: ''Dark colors'' are generally inert. ''Light green'' – inert to weak white in long wave, generally inert in short wave; ''light yellow'' – inert to weak green in long wave, generally inert in short wave; ''white'' – inert to weak  in long wave, generally inert in short wave; ''light purple'' – inert to weak white or weak brownish red in long wave, generally inert in short wave; some ''dyed lavender colors'' – moderate to strong orange in long wave, weaker in short wave
color: Apple-green, emerald-green, bluish green, leek-green, purplish blue, greenish white, white, black, may show green spots, rarely blue or violet; colorless in thin section. Often also banded.
twinning: Single and lamellar twinning on [100] and [001]

name: Johannsenite
color: blue-green, grey-white, dark brown, colourless

color: Light pinkish brown

name: Kosmochlor
caption: Chromite (metallic black), kosmochlor pyroxene (emerald green to dark green to black), chromian jadeite pyroxene (green), chromiferous arfvedsonite amphibole (green or gray), symplectite (green, a finely-crystalline mineral mix of mostly chromian jadeite)
habit: Prismatic crystals and fibrous aggregates
color: Emerald-green
pleochroism: X = yellowish green; Y = blue-green, grass-green; Z = emerald-green

name: Pigeonite
caption: Polarized light microscope image of part of a grain of orthopyroxene containing exsolution lamellae of augite The texture documents a multistage history: (1) crystallization of twinned pigeonite, followed by exsolution of augite; (2) breakdown of pigeonite to orthopyroxene plus augite; (3) exsolution of augite parallel to the former twin plane of pigeonite. (long dimension 0.5 mm, [[Bushveld igneous complex]])
habit: Prismatic crystals, to 1 cm; granular, massive.
color: Brown, greenish brown-black
twinning: Commonly twinned simply or multiply on {100} or {001}
pleochroism: Weak to moderate; X = colorless, pale green, brown; Y = pale brown, pale brownish green, brownish pink; Z = colorless, pale green, pale yellow

pleochroism: Strong in kunzite: α-purple, γ-colorless; hiddenite: α-green, γ-colorless

name: Gmelinite-Na
habit: Hexagonal plates, or short prisms, showing hexagonal dipyramids, pyramids and basal pinacoid.  {10 {{overline|1}} 0}, {10 {{overline|1}} 1} and {0001} dominant.  May also be tabular or rhombohedral. Crystals are striated parallel to (0001)
color: Colorless, white, yellow, orange, pale green, pink, red, brown and grey
other: [[Piezoelectric]].  Barely detectable radioactivity.  As with all zeolites, water is released on heating, and almost all has been expelled by 400 °C.
twinning: Interpenetrant twins common on {10 {{overline|1}} 1}.  The twins consist of four individuals, three are at 90° to the other and at 60° to each other

name: '''Stilbite'''
habit: Thin tabular, aggregates sheaf-like or in bow-ties, also fibrous and globular.
color: Usually colorless, white or pink
fusibility: Easily fused by blowpipe (~1050 °C) to produce a white "enamel"
